t: Proverbs 20
Wine*pn is a mocker, strong drink a brawler, and*ld whoever is led astray by it is not wise.
The*ln terror of a king is like the growling of a lion; whoever*ld provokes him to anger forfeits his life.
It*ln is an honor for a man to keep aloof from strife, but*ld every fool will be quarreling.
The*ln sluggard does not plow in the autumn; he*ld will seek at harvest and have nothing.
The*ln purpose in a man’s heart is like deep water, but*ld a man of understanding will draw it out.
Many*ln a man proclaims his own steadfast love, but*ld a faithful man who can find?
The*ln righteous who walks in his integrity— blessed*ld are his children after him!
A*ln king who sits on the throne of judgment winnows*ld all evil with his eyes.
Who*ln can say, “I have made my heart pure; I*ld am clean from my sin”?
Unequal*ln weights and unequal measures are*ld both alike an abomination to the Lord.*s
Even*ln a child makes himself known by his acts, by*ld whether his conduct is pure and upright.
The*ln hearing ear and the seeing eye, the*ld Lord*s has made them both.
Love*ln not sleep, lest you come to poverty; open*ld your eyes, and you will have plenty of bread.
“Bad,*ln bad,” says the buyer, but*ld when he goes away, then he boasts.
There*ln is gold and abundance of costly stones, but*ld the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
Take*ln a man’s garment when he has put up security for a stranger, and*ld hold it in pledge when he puts up security for foreigners.
Bread*ln gained by deceit is sweet to a man, but*ld afterward his mouth will be full of gravel.
Plans*ln are established by counsel; by*ld wise guidance wage war.
Whoever*ln goes about slandering reveals secrets; therefore*ld do not associate with a simple babbler.
If*ln one curses his father or his mother, his*ld lamp will be put out in utter darkness.
An*ln inheritance gained hastily in the beginning will*ld not be blessed in the end.
Do*ln not say, “I will repay evil”; wait*ld for the Lord,*s and he will deliver you.
Unequal*ln weights are an abomination to the Lord,*s and*ld false scales are not good.
A*ln man’s steps are from the Lord;*s how*ld then can man understand his way?
It*ln is a snare to say rashly, “It is holy,” and*ld to reflect only after making vows.
A*ln wise king winnows the wicked and*ld drives the wheel over them.
The*ln spirit of man is the lamp of the Lord,*s searching*ld all his innermost parts.
Steadfast*ln love and faithfulness preserve the king, and*ld by steadfast love his throne is upheld.
The*ln glory of young men is their strength, but*ld the splendor of old men is their gray hair.
Blows*ln that wound cleanse away evil; strokes*ld make clean the innermost parts.
